title: Open Education and the Traditional university
segmentation: OK. To start this workshop I was.
Thinking about convincing the heart part of the audience, people in the very traditional universities in established markets, we all know that in.
At large parts of the world there is a booming higher education where.
New challenges are faced and where the traditional University models are simply no solution.

And of course there's the adoption of open goes very fast, but there are many universities in this in the US in Europe that have an established market and they could ask, why would we opt for open education?
And it's this case that I want to bring.
At.
Well, in this definition of the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation, we get some very good reason.
Open Education is a simple idea, essentially.
It's about not noticing that technology has made a profound change.
The web has altered the possibilities of delivering knowledge of sharing knowledge and open education is one way to cope with this.
Now what does this mean for the University?
Well, if you think nothing has changed, of course you have to do nothing at then.
There is no problem at all, but.
I think many things have been changing.
For example, what the economy now is about is what we call the knowledge, economy and economy that creates knowledge that produces knowledge that distributes knowledge.
This is what.
New companies are all about is about.
Making this supply chain of knowledge working.
And whatever you call it, whether you call it a learning economy or the creative industries or whatsoever, it's all about this reality that are in this field.
Process is are aimed at this knowledge generation at an ever increase.

Base and this means of course, that the business of the universities which was for ages their own field of work being the places where you worked on knowledge and where you had these libraries, etc now faces a very increasing competition.
We are no longer the only ones who are engaged in producing knowledge, and we get computation of private professional trainings of.
Companies that have their own universities etc.
And a lot of new tools to deliver this knowledge.
So there is a diversification in the supply change of supply chains for knowledge.
And this means that in this changed higher education environment where you have this absolute pervasiveness of ICT, which has a lasting impact at a fraction of the cost, I could show you.
But it's an internal document.
The fraction of the cost of ICT at our University compared to the real estate costs.
You do not even see it in the graph.
ICT is really inexpensive.
Is something transformation?
Ull because it is so much less expensive than your buildings.
Your auditoria where you have these classes of three 400 students?
Well, you can reach now thousands of students through the computer at a fraction of the cost.
And this way the universities can prepare for a new workforce of highly mobile people that are well equipped with devices and that can work for multiple employers.
I have currently not one assistant at my office in the University who only works for me not well.
They all have two or three jobs.
They work one lives in London, one lives in Paris.
They worked for me on projects, so the whole idea of the University as the place where people gather to do this work has dissipated.
At.
And then who are we going to teach well?
It's no longer only this on campus students we are now aiming our scope starting from the future learners.
There are a lot of activities to attract junior college students for science.
All these initiatives about attracting people for stem.
Disciplines for science, technology, etc.
This is all aimed at future future learners.
If I look at external education budget of our University, a very large part is oriented to this new target groups to attract the right candidate.
Students.
In the past these were the students that lift nearby you at your University and the students just came to the University.
Well now they came.
They come from all over the globe and you want to attract the right students with the right profiles.
And then it doesn't stop.
With this on campus students because.
You want to keep Contacts with your alumni.
You want to have professional networks.
You want to support lifelong learners and you want to engage with stakeholder communities.
At.
1/3 issue is that learning has changed not only the business of transferring knowledge etc but also learning.
We discovered that a lot of learning is done in informal settings on the job settings etc and their new knowledge is growing.
For example, we now have at the University or Regional innovation network with a lot of spinoff companies that generate knowledge in the work place and this knowledge.
We want to have in the University.
And so you're thinking, OK, but what has?
All this today.
With open I'll come out onto that.
It also means that these mobile workers and mobile students of today.
Organize their own learning so it's no longer the University that has to take the lead in organizing.
Learning for the students.
This is something from the past.
Students organize their learning, they organized with their tools all the materials they need to learn.
And this means that the University needs to adapt, adapt its operations.
How are we going to do about our business adapting our teaching models or logistics or delivery models and explore new revenue models?
And.
Open we will argue is a value proposition in each of those scenarios.
If you miss the dimension of openness.
You miss you miss that what has crossed all these transformations and you are.
In a world of illusion.
So I think now what are the applications of open in all these aspects?
Well, for example, open courses are very good means to attract the right students to your University because they not.
They not only can read the descriptions of your courses, they can really see the teachers in action.
They can see the contents.
They can judge whether they are fit to follow this conference.
Very important for months and I think people in the most community have very well understood that that you have to show students.
This is the exact level of models that you need, but it also holds for language and I see at my University that now also the language people are publishing.
Openly tests and documentation in courses because they want the people with the right level of English and the right level of French to attend their classes.

And the best way is just to show it so that the student in the vacation time when he finished high school can really feel and see whether we can follow the classes, whether he is something appealing for for him.
It also offers flexible crossovers because you could do this all in a closed environment, but then you miss a lot of opportunities.
For example, that student in History discovers that there are very nice ways of infographics that are developed in the Sciences, and maybe that he can use this for his learning.
So by opening up we see an exchange of views.
I can give example of that in my courses.
Now I use mind Maps.
Well, I learn to use Maps in an open course on physics.
10 years ago I followed a course on hydrostatics an they had all over mind Maps.
Well now we use it in history teaching.
So this is what openness is about.

And of course, updating your course contents because all those of you that are working at universities you know that many syllabi are outdated or flatly outdated because the professor is publishing in a rated journals is cause is something he has to do on the sidelines.
Well, if you put your course open online, everyone can see it.
Every typo, every mistake, every election of.
Good judgment is open to the world, so you have to correct it.
And this means that in this new globalized context, we need to select also differently.
We cannot say, OK, we are living University.
People will have heard of us and they will come to us.
No, we will have to show what we want.
Our added value is we will have to show where we fit in the learning part of the student.
And this is based on an open way.
We did this in love and for an advanced course in literature which we launched as an.

Open book and we attracted students from countries where we didn't have cyantific relations with already many Latin American countries seem to have students that were well prepared for our contents and of the few hundred students that follow this book, 3 have applied now for a PhD at our University.
So we discovered these students through an open course.

And of course it wasn't looking and I think books are one of the hot is over one of the hot issues in 2012 about open courses is just one format, and I notice that there is a lot of discussion nowadays in universe.
It is about spokes, about small private online courses, something that many traditional universities Now re discover us because they are hesitant about open and they think oh, but let's use these.
This online technologies in a Safeway where we select the students where we offer entrance and these are these spokes.
Well of course books.
Are using this open technologies, but there is a big butt in it.
You failed to use a lot of the advantages of open courses your spoke.
No one will find it.
You have to advertise it yourself, whereas an open course attracts students, students you never heard about.
But you have the skills you might need in the future.
So do not overestimate your selection power.

You also like the serendipity of people finding your materials and understanding that it could apply to what they are doing, and I think we agree that many of the jobs of the future don't exist today, so it's our people who study.
For example, I have a social geographies who learn statistical technology techniques.
Well, he note.
Notice that in big data analysis these techniques are used and now he has a company where he does advertising studies with big data analysis.
But it's social geographies.
But he invented his own job by having input online.
It are not his professors of social geography who learned him this.
That's what we have to know this so.
Don't, please don't fall in the trap of those spokes.
That is very costly.
You will have to invest in all these technologies and you lack the basic message of open.
At.
One example of how.
Open courses are transforming universities.
Is that learning spaces are changing.

We made a major investment that are University in U learning spaces several hundreds of new study spaces where the students take takes control of this learning is no longer in an auditorium, is in a social space and there he wants only slept up.
He wants to download the courses.
He wants to annotate them.
He wants to.
Remix them, reuse them an we are seeing that student communities are producing student versions, of course, so they take an open course.
They adapt it with what the teachers told them in class.
They make better ski, better scheme, us better infographics and they put it online for each other again.
And this is the OR attitude that you see in many.
Universities now and what can universities then invest in when they put their own courses openly for free?
What are they getting in return?
Well, a lot of knowledge about your course when.
Highly expensive professor is teaching in a closed room.
Without control, without serve, without knowing what is happening there.
You do not manage.
You do not have the management capacity to intervene and to make these courses better and to make this education better.
When you put your Moocs online like several universities are now doing.
You get the possibility to measure everything that is happening every class hour, every lecture.
You can have statistics you can see.
Hey in this video, half of the students, after awhile they just drop out of the video.
Why is this?
This exercise?
Well, 75% of the students do not.
Manage to do it.
Why is this?
These are all things that we couldn't manage in the classical classroom.
You just teach your class, it's gone.
You have no recording, you know management capabilities.
And then of course rule that the universities should look into is how are they going to reposition themselves?
In this open world and there one of the opportunities of course, is to focus on the certification aspect of saying OK. You can follow open courses.
You can show us that you have gained expertise and we will test it for you and we will give you credit.
So this whole certification will be one of the aspects and also their open is an added value because certification means to claim that someone has.
Obtain certain competence as well.
In the past we just set over these students of David Ellefson.
We will have this competence is of course in a global market.
It doesn't work that way.
You have to say.
He proved these types of mathematical skills.
He did a course on aeronautical engineering at that level.
And you have to prove this so you have to be open and transparent also about your certification process is.
And this means that I think University should look at themselves what they do best and that is research and just think about how do we do research?
Well, we do research in an open way already.
For centuries open has been invented in research and for good reasons.
In research, we collaborate with colleagues all over the world.
We reuse their insights by quoting their articles and by not running over the same thing again unless for testing it and valid ifying.
Then we come hopefully to invent inventions that we share in the University community, and this is the leadership of the University in research.
And the excellence of the universities.
How much?
Publications, does it make WHI?
Don't we do this for our courses?
Why are we public for research and are we closed for education?
The message we are having is as research institutions.
University should be the first adopters of open education and this is the essence of what I wanted to communicate today.
Thank you.
